Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Country Oven Bakery recognizes management?s responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the Bowling Green facility.

To accomplish the company?s goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established a Plant Safety Program.  The objectives of the Plant Safety Program are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering and the economic burden resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.

One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA?s Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  Mr. Eric J. Smarko, Plant Engineer, is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.

The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, environmental impact and avoid physical property damage.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved a necessar

y.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.

In addition to the Plant Safety Program, the Country Bakery facility follows the following corporate and site-specific safety guidelines:
-Employee Handbook Plant Safety Rules
-Kroger Company Contractor Safety Rules
-Kroger Company Manufacturing Safety Key Element Assessment (KEA) &
Management
-Kroger Company Behavioral Accident Prevention Process (BAPP) Steering Committee
-General Office (GO) Safety Inspection Program and Abatement Plans
-Job Safety analysis (JSA) departmental Program

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Country Oven Bakery is part of the Kroger Company.  The facility manufactures frozen dough products and bakery items.  It operates an ammonia refrigeration system to provide cooling and freezing capabilities.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in the system is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum inventory in the system is approximately 20,000 pounds.  Since an ammonia release from the system could pose a risk of offsite public and/or environmental impact and the system regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119), the system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA?s RM program.

Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Process Safety Management Program consists of the following elements:  

Employee Participation - The purpose of the Employee Participation Program Element, upon implementation, is to provide for a cooperative participatory environment and necessary flow of information from management to employees and from employees to management.  This flow of information on process safety is expected to help eliminate or mitigate the consequences of catastrophic releases of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace.  Specifically, the Employee Participation Program Element is intended to involve appropriate employees at an elemental level of the PSM Program, particularly in the

development of the PSM Program; and to ensure that all potentially affected employees have access to the information developed under the PSM Program.

Process Safety Information - The purpose of the Process Safety Information Program Element, upon implementation, is to provide clear instruction for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety information.  The existence of written operating procedures is important so that those employees working on a process perform a given task in the same manner.  There is then less likelihood that incidents will occur since even a new employee or one who is relatively inexperienced will respond to a given event in a considered and prescribed manner.

REQUIREMENTS AND CONTENT 

TABLE OF CONTENTS

1.PROPERTIES OF AMMONIA
2.AMMONIA SAFETY DATA
3.AMMONIA MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEET (MSDS)
4.BLOCK FLOW DIAGRAM
5.PROCESS CHEMISTRY
6.AMMONIA INVENTORY

8.CONSEQUENCES OF OPERATING OUTSIDE OPERATING LIMITS
9.MATERIALS OF CONSTRUCTION
10.ELECTRICAL CLASSIFICATION
11.RELIEF SYSTEM DES

Process Hazard Analysis -  The purpose of the Process Hazard Analysis Program Element, upon implementation, is to analyze the hazards associated with a process covered by OSHA's PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 (as defined in 29 CFR 1910.119(a)) and EPA?s RMP Standard 40 CFR Part 68.  Specifically, the Process Hazard Analysis Program is aimed at identifying, evaluating, and controlling the hazards of the process and taking the necessary corrective and preventive actions to prevent recurrence of non-conformities or deficiencies in products, procedures, processes, or the PSM Program.

Operating Procedures -  The purpose of the Operating Procedures Program Element, upon implementation, is to provide clear instruction for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety information.  The existence of written operating procedures is im

portant so employees working on a process perform a given task in the same manner.  There is then less likelihood that incidents will occur since even a new employee or one who is relatively inexperienced will respond to a given event in a considered and prescribed manner.

Training - All employees who operate, maintain and repair ammonia refrigeration equipment at Country Oven Bakery must be trained in order to safely perform all necessary duties. 
This guideline contains general instructions for conducting initial and refresher training for ammonia refrigeration personnel.

Contractors - The purpose of the Contractor Safety Program Element, upon implementation, is to establish a screening process for contractors who perform work in and around covered processes.  The purpose of the screening is to help ensure that contractors who are hired and used can accomplish the desired job tasks without compromising the safety and health of employees at a facility.

Pre Startup Review - The purpose of the Pre-Startup Safety Review Program Element, upon implementation, is to ensure that certain other PSM activities have been performed before the startup of new or modified facilities involving a process covered by OSHA's PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  Specifically, the Pre-Startup Safety Review Program is aimed at making sure that certain important safety considerations have been addressed and that adequate safety measures are in place and operational, before any highly hazardous chemical is introduced into a process.

Mechanical Integrity - The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity Program Element, upon implementation, is to provide assurance of quality and on-going integrity of critical process equipment, maintenance materials, and spare parts & equipment, covered by OSHA's PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  This purpose is to be achieved in order to prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic events.  Specifically, the element is aimed at ensuring that critical process

equipment and components are fabricated, installed, inspected, tested, repaired and maintained properly by qualified personnel.

Moreover, the written procedures for the Mechanical Integrity Program Element are intended to have adequate detail to ensure that the specific process equipment receives careful, appropriate, regularly scheduled maintenance to ensure its continued safe operation

Hot Work - The purpose of Hot Work Permits is to establish the means for employees to control, in a consistent manner, Hot Work conducted in process areas.  
Specifically, this procedure is concerned with the permitting of Hot Work operations to ensure employees are aware of the Hot Work being performed and that appropriate safety precautions are being taken prior to beginning the work.

Management of Change -  The purpose of the Management of Change Program Element, upon implementation, is to manage changes that affect a process covered by OSHA's PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  Specifically, the Management of Change Program Element is aimed at identifying, reviewing, and authorizing changes prior to their implementation in order to assess the potential impact on safety and health of employees and to take the necessary actions to reduce any impact.

Incident Investigation -  The purpose of the Incident Investigation Program Element, upon implementation, is to analyze the hazards associated with a process covered by OSHA's PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 (as defined in 29 CFR 1910.119(a)).  Specifically, the Incident Investigation Program is aimed at identifying the cause of the incident under study.  If necessary, it is intended that the investigation will result in recommendations for taking the necessary corrective and preventive actions to prevent recurrence of non-conformities or deficiencies in products, procedures, processes, or the PSM Program that may have led to or caused the incident.

Compliance Audits - The purpose of the Compliance Audits Program Element, upon implement

ation, is to verify compliance of the PSM Program with OSHA's PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPA?s RMP Standard 40 CFR Part 68.  Specifically, the Compliance Audits Program Element is aimed at: gathering sufficient facts and information (including statistical information) to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the PSM Program are adequate and are being followed; and taking the necessary corrective and preventive actions to prevent recurrence of non-conformities or deficiencies in products, procedures, processes, or the PSM Program.

Five-Year Accident History

There have been no ammonia-related incidents at the Country Oven Bakery within the last five years that have resulted in onside or offsite impacts.

Emergency Response Program

An emergency response program has been implemented at the Country Oven Bakery facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  This program has been coordinated with the Bowling Green Fire Department.

The Emergency Response Program consists of the following elements:

-Emergency Recognition
-Coordination with Outside Parties
-Personnel Roles, Chain of Command, and Training
-Safe Distances, Evacuation Routes, Site Security
-Emergency Medical Treatment and First Aid
-Decontamination
-Post Emergency Response
-Post Incident Critique of Response and Follow-up

Planned Changes to Increase Safety 

-Country Oven Bakery is coordinating a mock drill with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), this drill will be coordinated with outside agencies.

-Country Oven Bakery will be submitting a Capital Appropriations request to install railing on top of the cooling towers.

-Country Oven Bakery will be updating the P&ID?
